official-title.#text: To establish a competitive grant program assisting the development of innovative early learning curricula for low-income children.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Education and the Workforce

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: suggests that 21.8 percent of children under the age of 18 are living in poverty.

text.#text: Research conducted by the

Research conducted by the Bureau of the Census of the Department of Commerce shows that socioeconomic status and family background characteristics are highly correlated with educational outcomes, with a concentration of low-performing schools in low-income and underserved communities.

As an example of an innovative early learning curriculum producing tangible results for low-income children, an independent evaluation of the Total Learning Curriculum developed by Action for Bridgeport Community Development, Inc., in cooperation with the Dr. Edward Zigler of the Yale Child Study Center and implemented in Bridgeport, Connecticut, has demonstrated that students who received all the elements of the Total Learning Curriculum made an average 2-point gain on the Diagnostic Reading Assessment (DRA) compared to an average 1.76-point gain on such assessment by those students who did not participate in the Total Learning Curriculum.

Such independent evaluation also showed that students who received all elements of Total Learning Curriculum have an average score of 22.35 points on the Concept of Print assessment, compared to an average score of 20.82 points on such assessment by those students who did not participate in the Total Learning Curriculum.

According to the findings of such independent evaluation, children with low initial DRA scores, high-family risk levels, low parental involvement, have special needs, or who are English-language-learners or participate in extended-day programs, make significant DRA gains after receiving all the elements of the Total Learning Curriculum.
It is the purpose of this Act to promote academic success for children living in poverty by—
improving and promoting school readiness by enhancing the cognitive, social, and emotional development of children from birth;
focusing such enhancements on low-income children who are at the greatest risk of negative educational outcomes; and
harnessing the most current developmentally appropriate educational methods to improve the public education system, including—
educational interventions beginning as close to birth as possible;
a child-initiated learning process with time for independent inquiry and play;
access to wraparound social services, including support for nutrition, housing, and family literacy;
professional development for instructional staff, including elementary school teachers, paraprofessionals, and pre-school teachers;
an extended school day and school year;
parent development, which includes providing parents with the knowledge and skills needed to be able to support a child’s growth and academic progress;
child-to-staff ratios of at least 1 early childhood or elementary educator for every 7 children; and

an enhanced transition from pre-kindergarten to elementary school, so that the cognitive and social gains of the pre-kindergarten program are sustained through the remainder of a child’s educational career.

header.#text: Grant program to close the achievement gap

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall award grants, on a competitive basis, to eligible partnerships to implement innovative early learning curricula in early childhood education programs and elementary schools in high-need communities for children from birth through age 9.

text.#text: From the amount appropriated under section 10, the
A grant under this section shall be awarded for a 5-year period and may be renewed for an additional 5-year period upon a showing of adequate progress, as determined by the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: a grant application at such time and in such manner as the
shall require, and containing the following information:

text.#text: To be eligible to receive a grant under this section, an eligible partnership shall submit to the

A description of the high-need community to be served by the eligible partnership, including the number and percent of English-language learners that will be served and other demographic and socioeconomic information as the
An assessment of the need for such a grant in the high-need community, including—
the number of low-income families; and
the number of and percent of elementary school children performing below grade level for reading and math on State assessments described in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 1111(b)(3) of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:1111/ss:b/p:3

text.#text: A detailed description of a plan to carry out the implementation of the innovative early learning curriculum in the high-need community, including—
how children and families will be selected to participate, taking into account the need for continuity and stability for all participating children and families;

how the implementation will coordinate and build on, and will not supplant or duplicate, professional development activities available to the staff of the innovative early learning curriculum in the high-need community;

how the implementation will train instructional staff in the innovative early learning curriculum to provide developmentally appropriate school-readiness services that are based on the best available child development and education research;

how the implementation will train instructional staff in the innovative early learning curriculum to meet the diverse educational needs of children in the high-need community, including children who have limited English proficiency, children with disabilities, or children with other special needs; and

how the implementation will train instructional staff in the innovative early learning curriculum to identify and prevent behavioral problems in children or working with children identified as or suspected to be victims of abuse.
A description of the plan for continuing the innovative early learning curriculum after the end of the grant period.
The proposed allocation and use of grant funds to implement the innovative early learning curriculum in the high-need community.
A description of the roles and responsibilities of the eligible partnership in implementing the innovative early learning curriculum in the high-need community.
An assurance, if applicable, that the eligible partnership will provide appropriate professional development to volunteers working directly with young children, as well as to paid staff.
A grant awarded under this Act shall be used to cover costs associated with implementing the innovative early learning curriculum, including—
costs for extended school hours and days;
costs associated with professional development, staff compensation, and retention;
costs for all comprehensive child and family support services; and
for any other activities needed to fulfill the purpose of this Act, as the

Not more 5 percent of a grant awarded under this Act may be used to pay the administrative costs (including supplies, office and classroom space, supervision, mentoring, and transportation stipends as necessary and appropriate) related to the implementation of the innovative early learning curriculum.
In awarding grants under this Act, the
award the first 5 grants to eligible partnerships from 5 different States; and
award not less than 1 grant to an applicant serving—
a school operated by the
a tribal educational agency; or
a high-need community located in a rural area.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: on the progress of implementing the innovative early learning curriculum. Such report shall include a description of—

text.#text: Each eligible partnership that receives a grant under this section shall submit an annual report to the

the actual service delivery provided through grant funds, including characteristics of the participating students (including descriptive information on the population of children and families served), and how the innovative early learning curriculum was implemented;
an estimate of the annual implementation costs of the program;
outcomes that are consistent with the purpose of the grant program, including—
improvements in student achievement;
improvements in language skills of children from birth to 3 years of age;
improvements in social-emotional outcomes for children at the greatest risk of needing behavioral or psychological intervention; and
improvements in health for children, including nutrition and access to stable high-quality health services;
the types of instruction, materials, and activities being funded under the grant program; and
the effectiveness of any training and ongoing professional development provided—
to the faculty, administration, and staff of early childhood and elementary educators within the eligible partnership receiving a grant under this Act; and
to the broader community of providers of social, emotional, behavioral, and related support to students participating in the program and to those who train such providers.
